Award.AwardTitle: Collaborative Research: Geometric Analysis of Computer and Social Networks
Award.AbstractNarration:
This project is to develop theoretic foundations and practical algorithms for geometric analysis of massive, weighted graphs arising from computer networking applications. The main challenge of understanding large scale computer networking is the decentralized management and operations on the network. How the global behaviors (for example, congestion) emerge from decentralized, local operations (routing) is still a mystery. Differential geometry studies the connection of local structures (such as curvatures) and global properties (such as topology and geodesics). Geometric analysis theorems often naturally lead to distributed algorithms that achieve global objectives, which is ideal in networking applications.

This project generalizes classical geometric analysis methods to massive graphs, the theoretic exploration focuses on the curvatures on graphs and the heat kernel estimates, relation between optimal transportation on graphs and curvatures, Ricci flow on graphs, and homology/cohomology/homotopy groups on directed graphs. The theoretic results will be applied for studying fundamental problems in computer networks, including: 1) Geodesics and network congestion: which aims to understand the connection of network congestion (e.g., on the Internet) with network curvature, and try to apply Ricci flow to alleviate network congestion by modifying local curvature; 2) Graph embedding and efficient routing: which investigates how to find an embedding of the network in geometric space in order to support greedy routing; and 3) Resource allocation in wireless networks: which applies optimal transport theory to the problem of capacitated base station allocation. The research results will be useful for applications in a broad range of fields, from pure mathematics research to theoretic physics, from telecommunication in engineering to brain imaging in medicine.

POR.DRECONTENT:
This project has developed theoretic foundations and practical algorithms for geometric analysis of massive, weighted graphs arising from computer networking and social networking applications.

The Ricci flow theory has been generalized to the discrete settings, which can control the Riemannian metrics by prescribing curvatures. The existence, uniqueness and convergence of solutions to discrete Ricci flow have been rigorously proven, and produces a discrete proof for the classical uniformization theorem, which can deform arbitrary shapes to three canonical planar domains. The discrete uniformization theory can convert all 3D problems to 2D ones, and unifies all kinds of shapes, greatly simplifies the geometric algorithm designs, improves the computational efficiency.

A profound connection between geometry and probability is discovered, which uses convex geometry to study the probability measure transformations. A variational approach has been established, which gives a constructive proof for the classical Alexandroff theorem also leads to a computational algorithm for optimal mass transportation. This method has broad applications from shape analysis in medical imaging to interpreting the blackbox of machine learning.

The Ricci flow method has been applied for graph mining applications. The main breakthrough we show is the excellent performance for approximate graph isomorphism. Graph isomorphism asks for checking whether two graphs are isomorphic. In our setting, we consider two graphs that differ by only a small percentage of nodes and edges. We mainly focus on complex networks that appear in the real world?such as the Internet backbone graphs and the social networks. The Ricci flow algorithm gives canonical metrics or both the facebook network and the LinkedIn network, by embedding the networks using these metrics, networks can be matched much more efficiently and accurately.

The project also leads to a solution to the classical "holy grid" problem, meaning automatically hexahedral tesselating solids with global regular structures. The holy grid problem plays a fundamental role in computational mechanics, numerical simulation and has been remained opening for tens of years. We apply surface foliation theory and show the equivalence between holy grids and measured foliations. The folicaitons can be constructed by special graph-valued harmonic maps . The the theoretic breakthrough leads to an automatic algorithm, which achieves the least number of singularities and singular curves of the hexahedral meshing. 

This theoretic discoveries and practical computational tools can be applied directly in computer or social network analysis,  surface registration and dynamic shape tracking, computer aided diagonsis, computational simulation   in mechanics, medical imaging and machine learning.
